properties.descriptio:
BAPTISMAL CERTIFICATE FILLED IN AND SIGNED IN HEBREW; (YIDDISH)... SIMILAR TO  DISPLAYED AT JEWISH MUS. OF N.Y. 1984; ONLY KNOWN JEWISH SCRIVNER; PRINTED FORM & FILLED IN WITH WATERCOLORS.



Made for Jacob Hartling, filled in by Wetzler on 4/26/1856, it is highly unusual as the birth date is 1829. It has Jewish Stars all over with Wetzlers icon Yiddish signature. It was printed in Allentown, Pa. by Blumer, Busch & Co.



This is important because of the scrivener, Martin Wetzler, was Jewish, a rarity in the Lehigh Valley at this time.  The PA German's referred to him as the Jewish Dindamann(Penman).   He knew Hebrew, German, & English.  He sometimes placed a Star of David & signed in Hebrew, on these Christian Certificates.  No one seemed to mind. (See Papers for Birth Dayes, Vol. II by Russell & Corinne Earnest)
properties.objects_customfield_6: JEWISH HERITAGE IN AMERICAN FOLK ART, 1984

See The Jewish Heritage in American Folk Art 1984 -- item 45, page 56.



This is important because of the scrivener, Martin Wetzler, was Jewish, a rarity in the Lehigh Valley at this time.

properties.descriptio:
A brass shell advertising mirror ..For Clothing, hats, caps, trunks and all kinds of men's wear come to my store...M. Bloom..established 1857...Clinton Street, Iowa City



In 1858 (1857 acording to the mirror),  Moses Bloom opened a clothing store in Iowa City, where it quickly became a successful business. Signs on his One Price Clothing House in 1864 advertised Furnishing Hats and Goods, Clothing and Tailoring Merchant. Bloom served as mayor of Iowa City for two years and later was elected to the state legislature.

properties.descriptio: Beth Zekeinim. Jerusalem

Map (Judaica) -  This map of Surinam is in black and white, printed circa 1720, indicating the Jewish held plantations, 2 Jewish synagogues, the Jewish market,; and related locations. Surinam, Dutch Guiana, territory of the Kingdom of the Netherlands located in N.E. South America, between Guyana, Brazil, and French Guiana and bordered on the north by; the Atlantic Ocean. The pre-1718 map held by the Collection shows only one synagogue, it this map the German synagogue is now the second.



As a historical note,  in 1627 a settlement was founded in the Berbice River, in Surinam, by Abraham van Pere, a Flushing merchant, and held by him under a licence (issued 12 July 1627) from the Company. Some historians believe that van Pere was a member of a Portuguese Jewish refugee family. He sent 40 men and 20 boys to settle at Nassau, about 50 miles upriver. Van Pere had a good knowledge of the territory since he had apparently been trading with the Amerindians of the area for a few years before 1627. He later applied his trading skills when he was contracted by the Zeeland Chamber to supply goods from Europe to the Dutch settlements in Essequibo.



Exhibited in the  year long in exhibit for the inauguration of the National Museum of American Jewish History located on Independence Mall in Philadelphia��_November 2010-11.

Print (Judaica) - Adas Israel by E. Klauber, a hand written contemporary note is glued to the print Entered according to Act of Congress by E. Klauber Most likely in Klauber's hand writing. The print is 3.5 x 4.5 without borders.  The synagogue was destroyed by fire in 1866 and rebuilt in 1868, this is a print of the new synagogue. This may have been published in the Occident as it was in Rabbi Leeser papers. Edward Klauber is listed in the 1859 Louisville Directory as an artist. Klauber is an early Jewish family in Kentucky. He was an active member of Adas Israel and listed as a Trustee in the 1890's.



Edward Klauber is listed in the 1859 Louisville Directory as an artist. Klauber is an early Jewish family in Kentucky. He was a active member of Adas Israel and listed as a Trustee in the 1890's.



One of the south central states of the United States; admitted in 1792. Its most important Jewish community is at Louisville (population, in 1900, 204,731, of which about 7,000 are Jews). Two brothers named Heymann, or Hyman, from Berlin, seem to have been the first Jews in Louisville (about 1814). An organized Jewish society appears in the directory for 1832; there are ten names, but no family of the present time claims descent from them. About 1836 there arrived some Polish Jews from Charleston, S. C., and some German Jews from Baltimore, Md., and some direct from Germany; they united in religious work, bought a graveyard, built a mi?weh, and engaged a sho?e?. A few wealthy Jews came from Richmond, Va., but they did not associate with the others and were absorbed by the non-Jewish element. 



The first regular minister was J. Dinkelspiel, whose signature to a neatly written ketubah dated 1841 is still shown. In 1842 the Adas Israel congregation was chartered; the family names of its incorporators still survive. In 1848 it elected B. H. Gotthelf as cantor and sho?e?, and when a secular school was established in 1854 he became its Hebrew teacher. In 1850 a synagogue was built on Fourth street between Green and Walnut streets, which was consumed by fire in 1866. A regular preacher, L. Kleeberg, from Elberfeld, Prussia, was then engaged, who remained till 1878. The secular school was abandoned in 1868, in which year a temple was finished, with a sexton's dwelling, and with Sabbath-school and meeting-rooms. In 1878 Dr. E. G. Hirsch became its preacher, but left in 1880, and, after a short interval, was succeeded by Dr. Adolph Moses (d. 1902). The present (1904) incumbent, Dr. H. G. Enelow, for a short time Dr. Moses' assistant, succeeded him. 

Synagogues. 



Adas Israel began with the West German minhag, but went further and further in the direction of Reform. It now uses the Union Prayer-Book, and has Sunday services in addition to the Sabbath

properties.descriptio:
Levytype Portrait (Judaica) - Hyman Gratz in a distiguished pose sitting in a chair...and facsimile signature. No doubt done from a portrait: however I can not find it listed in any Institution. It was done by Levytype Co.,  Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. The Levy brothers, Louis and Max, were extremely important in the history of photomechanical printing in the United States because Max eventually perfected the creation of the half-tone line screen used by most engravers...Sheet 6 x 9...oval image 3.5 x 4.5...circa 1880





American merchant and philanthropist; born in Philadelphia Sept. 23, 1776; died Jan. 27, 1857; educated in the public schools of his native city. In 1798 he joined his brother Simon in partnership as wholesale grocer, and later turned his attention to life-insurance. In 1818 he was elected director of the Pennsylvania Company for Insurance on Lives and Granting Annuities, and twenty years later was elected president of the company. On the founding of the Pennsylvania Academy for Fine Arts, in which his brother Simon Gratz took some part, he served on the directorate of the institution (1836 to 1837), and held the office of treasurer from 1841 to 1857. On the retirement of Hyman Marks as treasurer of the Congregation Mickveh Israel of Philadelphia Sept. 19, 1824, Gratz succeeded him, and was reelected annually until 1856. When the first Jewish Publication Society of America was projected in Philadelphia (1845) he was one of its managers. On the receipt in the United States of the news of the persecution of Jews in Damascus, Gratz was elected chairman of the meeting of the Congregation Mickveh Israel, called Aug. 27, 1840, to protest against that persecution.



By a deed dated Dec. 18, 1856, Gratz set asidestocks, bonds, and other property for the purpose of establishing a college for the education of Jews residing in the city and county of Philadelphia (see Gratz College).
properties.descript_1: Portrait of Hyman Gratz in a distinguished pose sitting in a chair, done by Levytype Co., Philadelphia, PA

properties.descriptio:
SATTERLEE U.S.A. GENERAL HOSPITAL, WEST PHILADELPHIA  IN COLOR BY MAGNUS; LISTS I.I. HAYES, SURGEON,U.S.V., COMMANDER; GREAT CIVIL WAR SCENE.



In the mid-19th century as an ambitious young country expanded its horizons westward, Dr. Isaac Israel Hayes, a young physician from an Orthodox Quaker family in the rural farmland of Pennsylvania, turned his eyes to the North. As a member of the harrowing American arctic expedition under the command of Dr. Elisha Kent Kane in search of the lost British explorer Sir John Franklin, Hayes became obsessed with making his own mark in the far northern polar regions. He organized his own privately funded voyage to the Arctic in 1860, during which he claimed to have reached a farthest north and to have stood on the edge of the fabled Open Polar Sea, a mythical ice-free zone in the high northern latitudes.



Through his own hard fought experiences, combined with the knowledge learned from native Greenlanders or Polar Eskimos, he successfully influenced the course of Arctic discovery, causing perceptive explorers to follow his guidance and lead. Directing the same ambition to humanitarian and social causes, during the devastating U.S. Civil War and as an elected politician in New York State during its Gilded Age, Hayes served the public good for a decade, with accomplishments as far reaching as his Arctic service, but little recognized even during his lifetime. In this book, which draws upon Hayes family papers, the little viewed diaries from Hayes s own expeditions, as well as other unpublished primary sources, the story emerges of a remarkable but forgotten explorer, writer, politician, and humanitarian who epitomized the rugged and restless spirit of adventure and individualism of 19th-century America. Illustrations. 



MAGEE, John. Saterlee U.S.A. General Hospital. Philadelphia: Lithographed and printed by Charles Magnus, published by James D. Gay, 1864. Chromolithograph (440 x 575 mm). 



Situated close to much of the fighting, but itself a safe haven, Philadelphia became the main site of U.S. military hospitals during the Civil War ��_ The 4,500 bed Saterlee Hospital, initially called West Philadelphia General Hospital, was located in an area bounded by present day Baltimore Avenue and Pine, Forty-third and Forty-sixth Streets. This hospital was opened June 9, 1862, under the supervision of Dr. Isaac J. Hays. This bird's eye view shows the hospital comprised of long wards surrounded by a wooden stockade. Troop encampments are set up in the surrounding grounds and soldiers can be seen marching in a neighboring field. The Hospital for the Insane and other identifiable buildings are depicted in the distance

 Rare slave dealer's business card, only known card from R. H. Davis  is of of Jewish family of slave dealers based in Richmond.



o       The Davis family were well known slave dealers |in Petersburg and Richmond, Virginia. 

             �_        The first generation was Benjamin, Ansley, George, and Solomon Davis of Richmond and Petersburg, Virginia went on the road and sold whole gangs of Blacks beginning in 1838.

             �_        I can not find an R. H. Davis listed in any form, but given the prevalence of the Davis slave trading clan in Richmond I assumed that he was a second generation. The|card is circa 1850-55.
